content: you can never have too many trees for your game hey guys welcome back to
another episode of black magic crafts today I'm gonna be making some trees I
recently started a new campaign with a new group and this adventure would take
place in the far north and I wanted to have coniferous trees spruce pine that
sort of thing there are a lot of really amazing ways that you can build pine
trees model railroad guys like Luke tones have been making fabulous-looking
hyper-realistic pine trees for a very long time don't really think that that
method is entirely appropriate for tabletop gaming when I decided to make
my set of pine trees I had two goals in mind the first is that these trees be
really rugged and durable I wanted to make sure that they could withstand a
fair amount of abuse I want it to be able to grab them from the actual tree
portion I didn't want to have to be careful and delicate with them so they
need it to be more rugged and more durable I also wanted them to be cheap
and made out of readily accessible materials things that people could get
in basically any City and I believe I achieved both these goals if you already
own some flocking which you should and if you already own some tacky spray
adhesive which you should then the materials needed to make a set of these
trees costs dollars you can make 20 trees for three dollars if you already
have the flocking and the glue its materials that I believe you can buy in
any city in the world Before we jump headfirst into this build I want to say
a quick thank you to my friends at dice bar.com
for sponsoring this build if you need to pick up a whole bunch of affordable dice
for your game especially if your dungeon master and you need a big
arsenal of dice dice pard comm will hook you up the best part is if you use the
promo code in the description of the video below you will get your entire
order shipped to you anywhere in the world expedited shipping for free and
that's a pretty good deal now let's build some trees the two main materials
in this build are wooden dowels and green scouring pads you want to take
your dowels and sharpen the ends of them into a point now you could do this with
an Olfa knife and it would work but it's slow and a little bit dangerous I
realized after doing one that there's a much better way a pencil sharpener yes
these wooden dowels are essentially just pencils so grab a pencil sharpener and
sharpen up all the points then you can start cutting the scouring pads into the
various layers for the tree and I found it was ideal to make three different
sizes so you could go from the widest at the base to the smallest at the top for
reference the widest ones were about two inches square and the smallest ones
about three quarters of an inch square once you have a whole bunch of these
squares cut you can start rounding them and you don't want to make perfect
circles you just want to make kind of roundish Ovilus shapes but you also want
to have a fair amount of variance at this point it's best to pre-paint the
wooden dowels before assembling the trees and I just used a really
watered-down dark brown acrylic craft paint to do this and then I use a scrap
piece of foam to act as a bit of a drying rack while the paint dried
assembling these trees could not be any easier all you need to do is take your
painted and sharpened dowel and a layer of the scouring pad take a bit of
generic PVA glue make a dab in the middle and just skewer the scouring pad
essentially you're just making a shish kabob here so if you've done that before
you can do this what you want to do is put a few layers of each size gradually
getting smaller towards the top to complete the very top of the tree I just
took some excess scrap a scouring pad and cut a triangle and
poked that on to the end and used a little bit of glue to hold it in place
and this made the point of the tree if you really don't care how realistic
these are and you just want something to serve a utility purpose on your gaming
table you could really consider these done at this point they will look good
enough to represent trees during your game but if you want to make them look a
little bit nicer a little bit more realistic you can move on to the next
step because I was going to be using an aerosol spray adhesive I wanted to
protect the painted wooden dowels on the bottom of the trees I didn't want them
to get all tacky so I wrapped them in toilet paper and used a tiny bit of tape
to hold them in place this way they wouldn't get covered in
the glue using some insulation foam I created another makeshift drying /
transportation rack this would be a way to hold all twenty of these trees while
I moved them to where I would be doing the spraying and where they could sit
and dry without me touching them my adhesive of choice for this is some 3m
77 spray adhesive this is really strong commercial grade stuff it bonds to just
about everything and it works really really well you want to give the tree a
good coating you want to spray it from the underside and the top side to make
sure that you get a hundred percent coverage once you have total coverage
with your tacky glue you can sprinkle on some fine turf any brand or variety will
work just fine I used woodland Scenic's pick the color
that you like but you do want to use a finer turf sprinkle on a lot of this
really cover it you don't want any missed spots don't worry you won't waste
any just make sure you have a clean dry newspaper underneath to catch all of the
excess because you can just pour it back in the bottle after one thing that is
very important to know with using this adhesive is that
it is really really strong as far as chemicals go you don't want to mess
around with this stuff you want to do it in a very well ventilated area or
outside if possible you also really want to protect your work surface with
newspaper as the overspray gets everywhere you can base these trees in a
multitude of different ways for me the easiest and quickest way is to just grab
some XPS foam mill it down to about 3/4 of an inch thick and cut out some kind
of natural shapes on my props on hot wire table I made some of these big
enough to accommodate 3 trees some big enough for 2 and a few big enough for
one so that I had some variety when using these once your basic shape is cut
out you want to bevel the edges using a knife so that you get a bit of a gradual
Hill if you want you can make some surfaces a rocky face just by scraping
it or carving it if your terrain is only used for home use like mine is and it
just sits on a shelf between games these bases will be plenty durable however if
you're going to be doing a lot of gaming with these say at a store or in a club
and you're going to be transporting them the edges of the XPS foam bases will be
a little bit fragile and you should consider putting the XPS foam on a more
durable base like MDF giving the foam a coat of Mod Podge will of course make
them more durable and as usual I used my combination of black paint and Mod Podge
to also act as a primer to paint out the bases I first painted any of these
surfaces that were a rocky face and I did this really really simply by just
doing a coat of a kind of tan with a dry brushing of a white the rest of the
bases I just painted out in this kind of camo olive green afterwards I gave
everything a black wash really I was only concerned about getting the wash on
the stone bits but by default it got on the green a bit not a big deal as most
of that would later be covered while waiting for the washed
I gave the trees a clear coating this would really lock in all of that loose
fine turf so that it didn't shed everywhere and it would make them even
harder I used this krylon matte clear coat
because I wanted something that wouldn't apply any gloss whatsoever then I could
remove the toilet paper that was protecting the wooden dowels using some
tin snips where you could use something like garden shears you can cut the
wooden dowels at the length that you want them but you want to cut it into a
point then you can use that point to stab and kind of skewer into the foam
base creating a hole where it will securely hold this tree in place you
want to just use a little bit of hot glue inside that hole and it will be
really really strong I don't think these would ever break free or fall out to
decorate the green part of these bases you can apply some flocking to make it
look a little bit nicer now which flocking you use may depend on what
gaming surface you play on if you have a grass board that you've already made
it's a good idea to use the same turf they used on that so it would match if
you use something like a battle mat you can get away with doing whatever to
attach this flocking all you need to do is brush on some really really watered
down PVA glue and get total coverage on everywhere you want it to stick you can
then sprinkle on the fine turf again just like the trees you want to get a
lot on here so you get total coverage shake off and save the excess once they
are completely dry and there is no more wet PVA glue with you can give the basis
a coating in that same Kryolan clear coat that I used on the trees to lock in
all of those fine fibers the worst thing about flocking is
that if it's not secured it kind of gets everywhere but this clear coat really
gets rid of most of that overall I think these trees are a really
cost-effective way to build up your arsenal of terrain and they're really
not that difficult to make again I'd like to thank dice Bart for sponsoring
this build if you need to pick up any of the tools or supplies that I used in
this build you can head over to Blackmagic craft CA where I have my
essential equipment store with links to all of the stuff that I use and
recommend on Amazon purchasing through those links helps fund these videos the
other and best way that you can help fund these videos is by supporting
Blackmagic crafts on patreon if you really love what I do for the community
and you want to help me continue to do it supporting me on patreon is the
absolute best way that you can do that so I highly encourage you to check out
the page and see what it's all about I'd love to have you as the newest
member of the black magic craft Fellowship that's it that's all guys I
hope you found this video useful and inspiring and if you did hit that like
button and drop me a comment below if you make your own set of trees I'd love
to see them post some pictures in the tabletop crafters guild Facebook
community until next week guys Cheers and happy crafting
